title: How to Make Kilpatrick Oysters

steps.headline: Buy 12 fresh oysters.
steps.description:
It is important to get oysters that are still alive and have been harvested recently. Talk to you local seafood seller about their oysters, as it's ideal to get them within a few days of them being harvested. Once you ensure that the oysters are fresh, make sure they are alive and high quality by looking for:
Closed shells - Oysters with open shells out of the water are not alive and should not be eaten. A fresh, salty sea smell - If the oyster smells fishy or "off," it is no longer good to eat. A heavy feeling - Fresh, quality oysters feel heavier than you might expect by looking at them. This means that the shell is still full of seawater and has not dried up due to being harvested many days ago.

steps.headline: Precook the bacon on your stovetop.
steps.description: Dice your strips of bacon into small cubes while you heat a pan to medium-high. Put the diced bacon into the pan and cook it until the fat has rendered and the pieces are just getting browned. Once cooked, put the pieces on a paper towel to drain and throw away the excess fat in the pan. The bacon will cook a bit more once it's on the oysters, so it's fine to undercook it a bit.

steps.headline: Cover your sheet pan with rock salt to hold the oysters.
steps.description: Cover the bottom of a rimmed sheet pan with at least ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) of rock salt. The entire surface should be covered so that the oysters can be easily placed and the tray looks neat and cohesive. If you are going to cook the oysters on a barbecue grill, pick a pan that can go directly onto the grill. {{greenbox: Make sure all of your oysters will fit in your pan before filling it with salt. Simply set all of the oysters in the pan and make sure they will fit without touching.

steps.headline: Shuck the oysters.
steps.description: Put a knife-proof glove on your non-dominant hand and pick up an oyster with that hand. Grab your shucking knife with your other hand and insert it into the oyster at the hinge. Once the knife is inside, twist it to pop the oyster open. The empty halves of the shells can be thrown away.Tip: Shucking oysters can take some practice. Consider getting a couple of extra oysters to practice on. Having extras will ensure that you have enough to cook if you destroy a few.

steps.headline: Lay out the shucked oysters in the pan.
steps.description: As you shuck each oyster, place it in the pan. Gently nestle each oyster into the salt, making sure that the oyster is secure and won't roll over. None of the shells should be touching as the oysters are set in the pan.

steps.headline: Mix the bacon, Worcestershire Sauce, and pepper together.
steps.description: Put the bacon and Worcestershire Sauce in a small bowl and then put a pinch of pepper on top of them. Mix the ingredients together with a small spoon, which you can also use to put this topping onto the oysters.

steps.headline: Put a dollop of the bacon topping onto each oyster.
steps.description: Use a teaspoon to gently add the bacon to the oyster. Try to get the topping spread thinly over the oyster instead of piled in the middle. When portioning out the topping on the oysters, make sure that you have enough to put on each oyster. Put a small amount on each oyster at first and then add more to each one if you have extra.

steps.headline: Heat up your grill or broiler to a medium-high heat.
steps.description: If you are using a gas grill or oven broiler, simply set the controls to medium-high. If you are using a charcoal grill, you will need to light the coals and then let them burn until coals are created. You want the broiler or grill to be at a temperature of at least 400 °F (204 °C) before putting the oysters in, although a broiler is likely to be hotter. A gas grill or broiler will be quicker to get going but a charcoal grill will give the oysters more of a barbecue flavor.Tip: If you are using a charcoal grill, you will need to start the coals burning at least a half hour before you want to cook your oysters.

steps.headline: Place the pan of oysters in the oven or grill.
steps.description: Center the pan so that your oven or grill can be closed. Once closed, don't open it again until the cooking time is up. If you want to protect the bottom of your pan from getting marks from the grill, place a sheet of foil on the grill and then place your pan on top of that.

steps.headline: Cook the oysters for 6 to 8 minutes.
steps.description: In this time the oysters will cook and the bacon will crisp up nicely. They are done when the bacon is crispy and the oysters are no longer transparent. Check the oysters at 6 minutes. If they still look a bit transparent, let them cook a minute or two longer.

steps.headline: Remove the oysters from the oven or grill carefully.
steps.description: Use a hot pad or gloves to remove the pan. Keep the pan level as you move it so that the ingredients stay in the shells and the salt doesn't spill. Set the pan down on a heat-proof surface, such as a hot pad or trivet.

steps.headline: Squeeze lemon juice over all of the oysters.
steps.description: Each oyster just needs a little spritz of lemon juice. The acid of the lemon will make a wonderful contrast with the richness of the oyster and bacon.Tip: Don't drop lemon seeds into the oysters. To prevent this, put your hand under the lemon as you squeeze it. The seeds should be caught in your hand while the juice will drip between your fingers.

steps.headline: Sprinkle chopped parsley over the top of the oysters.
steps.description: Wash your parsley and then chop it finely. Then pick up the parsley with your fingers and sprinkle a pinch of it onto each oyster. The parsley gives a little color contrast to the oysters and adds a fresh taste as well.

steps.headline: Serve the oysters immediately.
steps.description: Kilpatrick oysters need to be served as soon as possible after they are cooked. This will help ensure that they are still warm when you eat them. Kilpatrick oysters don't keep well. While you could put them in your fridge and eat them the next day, they will be difficult to reheat and won't be as delicious.
